questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
An aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery is most likely to be causing damage to the optic chiasma, leading to vision loss in this patient.

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

Anterior communicating artery aneurysm: 

Anterior communicating artery (Acom) links the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is directed anterior and superior to the optic chiasma. The aneurysm will protrude in the posterior direction and will impinge upon the optic chiasma from above, leading to loss of vision.

Compression of the optic chiasma (central lesion) by an ACom aneurysm, will lead to bitemporal hemianopia i.e, loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and hence, these fibers will be compromised.

In the case of a bilateral peripheral lesion of the optic chiasma, binasal hemianopia will be seen.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma

Blood supply of optic chiasma: The left and right anterior cerebral arteries, along with the superior hypophyseal artery (branch of the internal carotid artery) form the blood supply of optic chiasma.

 

The given cadaveric image below is of the vascular structures (Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain.

 

Investigation: Digital subtraction angiogram is the definitive imaging modality for aneurysms arising from the circle of Willis. Other investigations are CT and MRI.

Other options:

Aneurysms of the anterior choroidal artery (option B) and middle cerebral artery (option C) aneurysms will not compress the optic chiasma as they are anatomically not in close proximity to be able to exert pressure on the chiasma and cause loss of vision.

Despite the anatomical proximity of the anterior cerebral artery (option D) to the optic chiasma, anterior communicating artery (Acom) aneurysm is the commonest intracranial aneurysm.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The vertical and downward descent of the spleen is prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament.

The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen. It attaches the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. 

When the spleen gets enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament along with the splenic flexure of the colon restricts its downward displacement. The enlargement of the spleen occurs towards the right iliac fossa and hence the spleen is directed obliquely.

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

Splenic ligament Attachments  Contents
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon -
Phrenicosplenic ligament The undersurface of the diaphragm to the spleen -
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney Tail of pancreas
Splenic artery and vein
Gastrosplenic ligament The greater curvature of the stomach to the upper pole of the spleen Short gastric vessels
Left gastroepiploic artery

 

Cross-sectional view of the spleen and its ligaments

 

The spleen becomes palpable when it is enlarged 2-3 times more than its normal size. A characteristic splenic notch can be felt in the medial border in an enlarged spleen. Also, fingers cannot be insinuated between the left costal margin and the enlarged spleen.

In the classical method of palpation, the right hand (with fingers pointed towards the left costal margin) is placed on the right iliac fossa. Palpation begins from the right iliac fossa towards the left hypochondrium in an upwards and lateral direction. Between each breath of the patient, the edge of the spleen can be felt.

In the hooking method, the hooked fingers of the right hand are placed under the left costal margin, and with the left hand, pressure is exerted over the posterolateral aspect of the lower thorax. Spleen is felt at the deep inspiratory phase.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section.
questions.solution:
The given histological image is a section of the tongue showing circumvallate papillae, the largest papillae of the tongue.

Circumvallate papillae are large cylindrical structures that are around 8-12 in number, covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

They are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis (not on the sides of the tongue) on the dorsal surface of the tongue. It is narrower at its base than its apex. 

Numerous taste buds (around 250 taste buds for each of the 8-12 papillae) are present within the papillary walls and they contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves. Serous glands of von Ebner empty via the ducts into the base of the sulcus.

Identification: They can be identified by their characteristic dome-shaped structure lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

Other options: 

Option A - Fungiform papillae are large, rounded, and red in color and are mainly present on the lingual margins and also on the dorsal surface of the tongue. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It is supplied by the lingual nerve.

Option C- Filiform papillae are minute cylindrical or conical projections that are mainly present on the dorsal part of the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. All except filiform papillae contain taste buds. They are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It is supplied by the lingual nerve.

Option D - Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges that are present bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, with associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

Fall from a height on an outstretched hand is one of the main causes of humerus fractures.

Course:

The musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7) is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. It emerges at the lower border of the pectoralis minor and pierces coracobrachialis. It then descends between biceps brachii and brachialis where it supplies a branch to the shaft of the humerus. Then it enters the elbow and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

It innervates all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm i.e., 

  • Biceps brachii - involved in flexion of elbow and supination of the forearm
  • Brachialis -  involved in the flexion of the elbow
  • Coracobrachialis - flexes the arm at the glenohumeral joint

Cutaneous innervation of the lateral aspect of the forearm is by a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve, namely, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm (C5, C6).

Hence, injury to the musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of supination of forearm (biceps brachii), weakness in flexion of the elbow (biceps brachii, brachialis), and loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm (lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm).

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm:

Muscles Origin Insertion Innervation
Coracobrachialis Coracoid Process of scapula The medial side of the midshaft of the humerus Musculocutaneous nerve
Brachialis Distal half of anterior aspect of the humerus Ulnar tuberosity Musculocutaneous and radial nerve
Biceps Brachii Short head: Coracoid process 
Long head: Supraglenoid tubercle		 Radial tuberosity Musculocutaneous nerve

The below image shows the anterior compartment of the arm

Other options: 

Option A:

Median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss over the radial 3 1/2 fingers and loss of thumb abduction. In high lesions, the long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles are also paralyzed. Wasting of the thenar eminence is seen in long-standing cases.

Option B:

Radial nerve injury can present with wrist drop, thumb drop, and finger drop. Extension of the elbow will be spared in lesions below the elbow. The extension of the IP joints is intact due to the action of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Loss of sensation over the first dorsal web space is observed.

Option D:

Ulnar nerve injury is characterized by ulnar claw hand, wasting of the hypothenar muscles and intrinsic muscles of the hand, and sensory loss over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand and medial 1 1/2 fingers.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
The most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection is the lingual nerve.

It loops around the submandibular duct and hence is susceptible to injury during submandibular gland resection.

Course:

The lingual nerve arises from the posterior trunk of the mandibular nerve (V3 branch of the trigeminal nerve). The lingual nerve descends between the tensor veli palatini muscle and the lateral pterygoid muscle, where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve. It then descends across the medial pterygoid muscle to enter the oral cavity. As the lingual nerve enters the floor of the oral cavity, it lies on the deep portion of the submandibular gland. It then passes into the tongue on the hyoglossus muscle where it is attached to the submandibular ganglion.

The submandibular duct lies between the lingual and hypoglossal nerves, superficial to the hyoglossus muscle. As the duct reaches the anterior border of the hyoglossus, it is crossed by the lingual nerve and lies in close proximity to the nerve. Hence lingual nerve injury is the most common.

Injury: 

The lingual nerve is at risk to be injured during submandibular gland resection because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required. Also, it is connected to the submandibular ganglion which will lead to the nerve being exposed within the operating field.

The manifestations of lingual nerve injury depend on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost. 

Note:

The cranial nerves that are at risk during submandibular gland resection include:

  • The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve
  • Lingual nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve

Other options: 

Option A: Nerve to mylohyoid is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and lies in the mylohyoid groove inferior to the mandibular foramen, hence the risk of injury is less.

Option B: Inferior alveolar nerve enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen, hence is unlikely to be injured during submandibular gland excision.

Option D: Hypoglossal nerve injury is less common than lingual nerve injury as it only lies below and parallels to the submandibular duct.

Related Pearl: Branches of mandibular nerve

Branches of mandibular nerve
Branches from the main trunk

Branches

Sensory and motor supply

Nerve to Medial Pterygoid (motor)

Medial Pterygoid

Tensor Tympani

Tensor Veli Palatini muscles

Nervous spinosus (sensory)

 Dura of the middle cranial fossa
Branches from the anterior division  

Muscular branches (motor)

 Lateral pterygoid and Masseter

Deep temporal nerves (2 branches)

 Temporalis muscle and periosteum of temporal fossa

Buccal nerve (sensory)

 Buccal mucosa
Branches from the posterior division  
Auriculotemporal and lingual nerve  Sensory supply

Inferior alveolar nerve (motor and sensory)

Mylohyoid

Anterior belly of the Digastric

Sensation to the lower teeth

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve.

Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, in this case for coronary bypass graft.

Saphenous nerve:

It is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

Saphenous nerve injury:

When the great saphenous vein is being harvested for coronary bypass graft, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein. Sensory loss over the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot is observed in saphenous nerve injury. 

Other options: 

Option A: Superficial peroneal nerve injury causes sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

Option C: Femoral nerve gives rise to anterior cutaneous branches, the saphenous nerve, and motor supply to the quadriceps and sartorius. Anterior cutaneous branches supply the skin on the anterior thigh and knee. If the saphenous nerve was not an option in the question, the femoral nerve would have been the next best answer. 

Option D: Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given sagittal section of the head and neck is the uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibers to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior third of the tongue.
  • Motor fibers to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibers for the postsulcal part of the tongue.

Pharyngeal plexus:

The nerve supply of the pharynx is mainly from the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. It is formed by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion. The vagus nerve provides the motor supply and the glossopharyngeal nerve provides the sensory supply.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate(except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx(except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

Note:

Previously cranial root of the spinal accessory nerve was thought to contribute to the motor functions of the pharyngeal plexus, but recent evidence suggests that it is not a major part of the motor drive to the pharyngeal plexus.

Innervation of the soft palate:

General sensation - It is mostly carried by the lesser palatine nerve which is a branch of maxillary nerve. The sensation from posterior part is carried by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and from the plexus around the tonsil which is formed by the tonsillar branches of the glossopharyngeal and lesser palatine nerves. 

Taste sensation - There are taste buds in the oral surface of soft palate and sensation from them is carried by the lesser palatine nerve.

Secretomotor supply - It is by the lesser palatine nerve via postganglionic fibres from the pterygopalatine ganglion.

Motor supply - It is by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve except for tensor veli palatini which is supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Related Pearl: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE

abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.
